revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/Oaklandfunk|Oaklandfunk]] ([[User talk:Oaklandfunk|talk]]): Revert use of copyvio image . ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Infobox comedian <!-- for individuals - see Template:Infobox comedian for usage --> | name = Moshe Kasher | image =Moshe Kasher (4463668533).jpg | image_size = | caption = Kasher at the SXSW Comedy Fest, 2010 | pseudonym = | birth_name = Mark Moshe Kasher | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1979|7|6}} | birth_place = [[Queens]], [[New York City|New York]], U.S. | medium = [[Stand-up comedy|Stand-up]], [[television]], [[webcast]] | nationality = [[United States|American]] | education = [[University of California, Santa Barbara]] | active = 2001–present | employer = | genre = [[Observational comedy]], [[black comedy]], [[surreal humour]] | subject = [[Everyday life]], [[Human sexuality]], [[self-deprecation]], [[religion]], [[Race (human categorization)|race]], [[politics of the United States]] | spouse = {{Marriage |[[Natasha Leggero]] |2015}} | children = 1 | parents = | relatives = | notable_work = | signature = | website = {{URL|http://moshekasher.com/}} }}
'''Mark Moshe Kasher'''<ref>{{Cite news |last=Wall |first=Alix |date=March 22, 2012 |title=Life’s no joke for Oakland-raised bad boy turned comic |url=http://www.jweekly.com/article/full/64610/lifes-no-joke-for-oakland-raised-bad-boy-turned-comic/ |newspaper=[[j. (newspaper)|j.]] |location=[[San Francisco]] |accessdate=April 16, 2016}}</ref> (born July 6, 1979)<ref name=WALLSTREET>{{cite news |title=Local Comic Puts His Pain on Paper |first=John |last=Letzing |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204369404577207183559813026|newspaper=Wall Street Journal |date=February 9, 2012 |accessdate=February 25, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite podcast|url=http://thechamps.libsyn.com/webpage/episode-1-guest-jerrod-carmichael |title=The Champs podcast with guest Jerrod Carmichael |website= |publisher= |host=Neal Brennan, Moshe Kasher and [[DJ Douggpound]] |date= |time= |accessdate=February 25, 2012}}</ref> is an American [[Stand-up comedy|stand-up comedian]], writer and actor based in the [[Los Angeles]] area.<ref name=WALLSTREET/><ref name=PUNCHLINE>{{cite news |title=Comic to Watch in 2010: Moshe Kasher |first=Dylan P. |last=Gadino |url=http://punchlinemagazine.tumblr.com/post/381308008/comic-to-watch-in-2010-moshe-kasher |newspaper=Punchline |date=December 31, 2009 |accessdate=February 25, 2012}}</ref> He is the author of the 2012 memoir ''Kasher in the Rye: The True Tale of a White Boy from Oakland Who Became a Drug Addict, Criminal, Mental Patient, and Then Turned 16''.
In 2009, [[iTunes]] named Kasher "Best New Comic" and his comedy album ''Everyone You Know Is Going to Die, and Then You Are!'' was ranked one of the top 20 comedy albums on iTunes that same year.<ref name=PUNCHLINE/><ref name=AVCLUB>{{cite web |url=http://www.avclub.com/article/moshe-kasher-isnt-gaybut-hes-close-40528 |title=Moshe Kasher isn’t gay—but he’s close |last=Nguyen |first=Tuyet |date=April 28, 2010 |work=A.V. Club |publisher=The Onion |accessdate=March 28, 2015}}</ref> He was also named "Comic to Watch in 2010" by ''Punchline Magazine''.<ref name=PUNCHLINE/>
== Early life and education == Born in [[Queens]], [[New York City|New York]],<ref name=EASTBAY2>{{cite news |title=Moshe Kasher Comes Home |first=Rachel |last=Swan |url=http://www.eastbayexpress.com/ebx/moshe-kasher-comes-home/Content?oid=3161439 |newspaper=East Bay Express |date=March 28, 2012 |accessdate=April 22, 2012}}</ref> Kasher moved to [[Oakland, California]] with his mother and brother when he was one year old,<ref name=WALLSTREET/><ref name=EASTBAY2/> and lived mostly on disability assistance and food stamps.<ref name="la weekly 2012">{{cite web|url=http://www.laweekly.com/arts/comedian-moshe-kashers-memoir-kasher-in-the-rye-i-was-violent-i-was-sexist-i-was-a-pig-2372167 |title=COMEDIAN MOSHE KASHER'S MEMOIR KASHER IN THE RYE: 'I WAS VIOLENT. I WAS SEXIST. I WAS A PIG.' |publisher=''LA Weekly'' |date=April 13, 2012 |accessdate=August 9, 2015 }}</ref> His parents split up when he was 9;<ref name="la weekly 2012"/> his father remained in New York, and Kasher visited him regularly until his death — Kasher was 20 at the time.<ref name=WALLSTREET/>
Kasher grew up in [[North Oakland, Oakland, California|North Oakland]]'s [[Temescal, Oakland, California|Temescal]]<ref name=WALLSTREET/> and [[Piedmont Avenue (Oakland, California)|Piedmont Avenue]] neighborhoods.<ref name="sf gate 2014"/> A son of deaf parents, Kasher worked as a sign-language interpreter from the age of 17.<ref name=WALLSTREET/><ref name=EASTBAY2/><ref name=FLAUNT>{{cite news |title=Moshe Kasher's Time in the Light |first=Justin |last=Pansacola |url=http://flaunt.com/blogs/editorialdepartment/moshe-kashers-time-light |newspaper=Flaunt |date= |accessdate=February 25, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402000449/http://flaunt.com/blogs/editorialdepartment/moshe-kashers-time-light |archivedate=April 2, 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref name=SFWEEKLY>{{cite news |title=Sketchfest Q&A: Moshe Kasher |first=Irene |last=McGee |url=http://blogs.sfweekly.com/shookdown/2010/01/_qa_with_moshe_kasher.php |newspaper=SF Weekly |date=January 19, 2010 |accessdate=February 25, 2012}}</ref> His parents met at the [[Deaflympics|World Games for the Deaf]] in 1967.<ref name="la weekly 2012"/> His father, Steven, was born to secular, [[Communism|communist]] [[Jews|Jewish]] parents. Kasher's paternal grandfather was [[Yiddish]] writer Duvid Kasher. Steven was a painter when he met Kasher's mother, and later became a [[Hasidic Judaism|Hasidic Jew]] in the [[Satmar (Hasidic dynasty)|Satmar community]] in [[Brooklyn]]. He was later diagnosed with [[Gaucher's disease]].<ref name="jewish weekly">{{cite web|url=http://www.thejewishweek.com/arts/books/here_absurdity |title=From Here To Absurdity |publisher=''The Jewish Week'' |date=April 17, 2012 |accessdate=August 9, 2015 }}</ref> Kasher's brother is a [[rabbi]].<ref name=SANDIEGO/><ref name=PORTLAND>{{cite news |title=In the Wry: Comedian Moshe Kasher |first=Rebecca|last=Walts |url=http://www.portlandmonthlymag.com/arts-and-entertainment/culturephile-portland-arts/articles/moshe-kasher-october-2011 |newspaper=Portland Monthly |date=October 27, 2011 |accessdate=October 7, 2012}}</ref>
In his autobiography ''Kasher in the Rye: The True Tale of a White Boy from Oakland Who Became a Drug Addict, Criminal, Mental Patient, and Then Turned 16'', Kasher wrote about having been moved in and out of mental institutions from the age of 4 and using drugs from the ages of 12 to 16. He was kicked out of four different high schools.<ref name="la weekly 2012"/> In an interview with SanDiego.com, Kasher described himself as "pretty straight edge," stating that he has been clean "since I was very young."<ref name=SANDIEGO>{{cite web |url=http://www.sandiego.com/articles/2011-07-20/living-edge-moshe-kasher |title=Living On The Edge with Moshe Kasher |last=Downs |first=Gordon |date=July 20, 2011 |work=SanDiego.com |accessdate=February 6, 2012}}</ref> He earned his [[General Educational Development|G.E.D.]] at age 16 and later became a sign-language interpreter.<ref name="la weekly 2012"/>
Kasher attended community college in the [[San Francisco Bay Area|Bay Area]], where he studied theater and wrote several long-form monologues.<ref name="la weekly 2012"/> He later transferred to the [[University of California, Santa Barbara]], where he graduated with a degree in religious studies and minored in Jewish studies.<ref name=WALLSTREET/><ref name="jewish weekly"/><ref name=SANDIEGO/> Prior to his career in comedy, Kasher had considered becoming a college professor in [[Jewish history]].<ref name=SANDIEGO/>
In 2001, Kasher attended an [[open mic]] comedy night in New York which included a performance by [[Chelsea Peretti]], a comedian and writer with whom Kasher had attended [[Middle school|junior high school]] in Oakland.<ref name=WALLSTREET/><ref name=SANDIEGO/> After seeing her perform, Kasher asked Peretti to take him along on future performances, offering to perform with her.<ref name=WALLSTREET/><ref name=SANDIEGO/> For his first performance, she took him to an open mic at the Luggage Store Gallery in [[San Francisco]].<ref name=SANDIEGO/>
==Career==
===Stand up=== In the early 2000s, Kasher performed mainly in [[San Francisco Bay Area|the Bay Area]], regularly performing at the Punch Line and Cobb's comedy clubs in [[San Francisco]].<ref name=WALLSTREET/><ref name=SFWEEKLY/><ref name=SANDIEGO/> In the mid to late 2000s, he participated in many comedy shows with fellow comedians [[Brent Weinbach]] and [[Alex Koll]].<ref name=SGATE2>{{cite news |title=Comedy Day: Top comics converge on Golden Gate Park to provide free chortles and guffaws |first=Reyhan |last=Harmanci |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2006/09/28/NSGIBJI9861.DTL |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |date=September 28, 2006 |accessdate=February 25, 2012}}</ref><ref name=SFIST>{{cite web |url=http://sfist.com/2008/01/15/sf_sketchfest_t.php |title=SF Sketchfest Ticket Giveaway: Brent Weinbach in Boomtime |last=Keeling |first=Brock |date=January 15, 2008 |work=SFist |publisher=Gothamist LLC |accessdate=February 25, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080708214802/http://sfist.com/2008/01/15/sf_sketchfest_t.php |archivedate=July 8, 2008 |df= }}</ref><ref name=EASTBAY>{{cite news |title=World of Punch Lines |first=Rachel |last=Swan |url=http://www.eastbayexpress.com/ebx/world-of-punch-lines/Content?oid=2295002 |newspaper=East Bay Express |date=December 22, 2010 |accessdate=February 25, 2012}}</ref> In 2008 Kasher moved to Los Angeles.<ref name=WALLSTREET/><ref name=EASTBAY2/><ref name=SFWEEKLY/>
2009 marked a significant year in Kasher's comedy career. He was named "Best of Fest" at that year's [[Aspen Rooftop Comedy Festival]];<ref name=PUNCHLINE/><ref name=AVCLUB/><ref name=SFWEEKLY/> his performance in Aspen garnered him an invitation to the ''[[Just For Laughs]]'' comedy festival in [[Montreal]] that same year.<ref name=SFWEEKLY/> This was followed by an appearance on the [[Comedy Central]] series ''[[Live at Gotham]]''.<ref name=SFWEEKLY/><ref name=SANDIEGO/> Kasher had also released his comedy album ''Everyone You Know Is Going to Die, and Then You Are!'' through Rooftop Comedy Productions in April 2009;<ref name=EASTBAY2/><ref name=SFWEEKLY/> near the year's end the album was deemed one of the top 20 comedy albums of 2009 on iTunes. Kasher was also recognized by iTunes as Top New Comedy Artist of 2009.<ref name=PUNCHLINE/><ref name=AVCLUB/>
Kasher's stand up act has been featured on such television programs as ''[[Late Night with Jimmy Fallon]]'' in 2010<ref name=WALLSTREET/><ref name=SANDIEGO/> and ''[[John Oliver's New York Stand Up Show]]'' in 2011.<ref name=PRESS1>{{cite press release |title=John Oliver and Friends are Back! The Second Season of 'John Oliver's New York Stand-Up Show' Premieres Thursday, March 24 at Midnight* |publisher=COMEDY CENTRAL Corporate Communications |date=March 7, 2011 |url=https://online.wsj.com/article/PR-CO-20110307-907971.html |accessdate=February 6, 2012}}</ref> He has appeared on ''[[Conan (talk show)|Conan]]'', [[Showtime (TV channel)|Showtime]]'s ''[[Larry Wilmore's Race, Religion & Sex]]''.{{Citation needed|date=December 2013}} He has also appeared as a frequent panelist on ''[[Chelsea Lately]]''.<ref name=WALLSTREET/><ref name=SANDIEGO/>
Kasher has performed at festivals internationally. In addition to the aforementioned Rooftop Comedy Festival and ''Just For Laughs'', in 2010, he appeared at [[Fun Fun Fun Fest]]<ref>{{cite news |title=2010 Fun Fun Fun Fest Update |first= |last= |url=http://austinist.com/2010/09/02/2010_fun_fun_fun_fest_update_this_n.php |newspaper=Austinist |date=September 2, 2010 |accessdate=February 25, 2012}}</ref> and [[South By South West]]<ref name=PORTLAND/><ref>[http://sxsw.com/node/6308 Moshe Kasher pictured with other comedians at the 2010 SXSW fest on sxsw.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120225110710/http://sxsw.com/node/6308 |date=2012-02-25 }}</ref> both held in [[Austin, Texas]], as well as [[Cat Laughs]] in [[Kilkenny]],<ref name=LAUGHSPIN2>{{cite news |title=Punchline Magazine’s dispatch from Kilkenny’s Cat Laughs Comedy Festival, part 1 |first=Jay |last=Richardson |url=http://www.laughspin.com/2010/06/03/punchline-magazine%E2%80%99s-dispatch-from-kilkennys-cat-laughs-comedy-festival-part-1/ |newspaper=Laughspin |date=June 3, 2010 |accessdate=February 25, 2012}}</ref> [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]], and the [[Sasquatch! Music Festival]] in [[George, Washington]].<ref>[http://sasquatchfestival2010.sched.org/event/21aa2923c4a9fe3c48938acb8967d17a Moshe Kasher's schedule on the Sasquatch! 2010 festival's website] Retrieved February 25, 2012.</ref> In 2011 he appeared at the [[Melbourne Comedy Festival]] in [[Melbourne, Australia]]. Kasher has also attended [[SF Sketchfest]] in [[San Francisco]], [[California]] on several occasions.<ref name=SFWEEKLY/><ref name=SFGATE>{{cite news |title='Rockridge rat' Moshe Kasher at SF Sketchfest |first=Kimberly |last=Chun |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2012/01/18/NSG61MO59R.DTL |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |date=January 19, 2012 |accessdate=February 25, 2012}}</ref><ref name=SFGATE2>{{cite news |title=SF Sketchfest: The comedy event, opening today, is bigger than ever |first=Reyhan |last=Harmanci |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2008/01/10/NS46U8VK3.DTL |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |date=January 10, 2008 |accessdate=February 25, 2012}}</ref>
In addition to the iTunes awards in 2009, Kasher was named "Comic to Watch in 2010" by ''[[Punchline Magazine]]''<ref name=PUNCHLINE/> as well as "One of the Top 20 Jews In The Arts" by ''Shalom Life'' in 2011.<ref name=SHALOM>{{cite web |url=http://www.shalomlife.com/culture/15127/top-20-jews-in-the-arts-moshe-kasher/ |title=Top 20 Jews In The Arts - Moshe Kasher |last=Baylen |first=Ashley |date=April 26, 2011 |work=Shalom Life |publisher=The Onion |accessdate=February 25, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131218151137/http://www.shalomlife.com/culture/15127/top-20-jews-in-the-arts-moshe-kasher/ |archivedate=December 18, 2013 |df= }}</ref> John Wenzel of ''[[The Denver Post]]'' also ranked Kasher #2 on his list of the top 10 comedy shows he attended in the Denver area during 2011.<ref name=DENVER>{{cite news |title=Best of 2011: 10 funny acts that said what we needed to hear when nobody else would |first=John |last=Wenzel |url=http://www.denverpost.com/search/ci_19604234|newspaper=Denver Post |date=December 24, 2011 |accessdate=February 25, 2012}}</ref>
In January 2012, Kasher recorded his first solo comedy special for Netflix, Moshe Kasher: Live In Oakland at The New Parish nightclub in his hometown of Oakland.<ref name=WALLSTREET/><ref name=BLACKLIST>{{cite web |url=http://www.theblacklistnyc.com/moshe |title=Moshe Kasher Comedy Special |year=2012 |work=The Black List NYC |accessdate=February 25, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{IMDb title|2229301|Moshe Kasher Comedy Special|(2012)}} Retrieved February 25, 2012.</ref>
In September, 2016 [[Comedy Central]] ordered a talk show series to be written and hosted by Kasher, entitled ''[[Problematic with Moshe Kasher|Problematic]]'',<ref name= "ccorder">{{cite news |last=O'Connell |first=Michael |url= http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/comedy-central-orders-moshe-kashers-931280 |title=Comedy Central Orders Moshe Kasher's 'Problematic' to Series |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=September 21, 2016 |accessdate=March 31, 2017}}</ref> which premiered on April 18, 2017.
In 2018, Moshe and his wife Natasha Leggero co-released a three part stand up special on Netflix entitled "The Honeymoon Stand Up Special"
===Writing=== Kasher is a published playwright, writer and author. While still in college, Kasher's long form [[monologue]] "Look Before You Leap" was included in the literary collection ''Monologues For Men By Men: Volume Two'' published in 2003.<ref>{{cite book |title=Monologues For Men By Men: Volume Two |editor1-last=Garrison |editor1-first=Gary |editor2-last=Wright |editor2-first=Michael |year=2003 |publisher=Heinemann |location= |isbn=0-325-00559-1 |page=49 |url=http://www.heinemann.com/products/E00559.aspx |accessdate=February 25, 2012}}</ref> In 2011 and 2012 he contributed several articles to ''[[Heeb]]'' magazine.<ref>[http://heebmagazine.com/tag/moshe-kasher A list of articles contributed by Moshe Kasher to ''Heeb'' magazine] Retrieved February 25, 2012.</ref> In 2012, he published his autobiography ''Kasher in the Rye: The True Tale of a White Boy from Oakland Who Became a Drug Addict, Criminal, Mental Patient, and Then Turned 16'' published by [[Hachette Book Group USA|Hachette Book Group]]'s Grand Central Publishing.<ref name=WALLSTREET/><ref name=FLAUNT/><ref name=LAUGHSPIN>{{cite news |title=Comedian Moshe Kasher’s book is going to be amazing |first=Dylan P. |last=Gadino |url=http://www.laughspin.com/2011/07/26/comedian-moshe-kashers-book-is-going-to-be-amazing/ |newspaper=Laughspin |date=July 26, 2011 |accessdate=February 25, 2012}}</ref> He wrote an episode titled "Pardon Me" for the television show, ''[[The New Normal (TV series)|The New Normal]]''.<ref name="sf gate 2014">{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/performance/article/Comic-Moshe-Kasher-returns-to-Punch-Line-5963835.php |title=Comic Moshe Kasher returns to Punch Line |publisher=''SF Gate'' |date=December 17, 2014 |accessdate=August 9, 2015 }}</ref>
===Acting=== Kasher played small roles in the independent films ''[[Sorry, Thanks]]'' (2009)<ref>{{IMDb title|1162125|Sorry, Thanks (2009)}} Retrieved March 28, 2012.</ref> and ''Wish Makers of West Hollywood'' (2010).<ref>{{IMDb title|1524560|Wish Makers of West Hollywood (2010)}} Retrieved March 28, 2012.</ref> He appeared on episodes of the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] [[sitcom]] ''[[Traffic Light (TV series)|Traffic Light]]'' in 2011<ref>{{IMDb title|1836709|Traffic Light: Season 1, Episode 11 - Where the Heart Is (3 May 2011)}} Retrieved March 28, 2012.</ref> and the [[NBC]] sitcom ''[[Whitney (TV series)|Whitney]]'' in 2012.<ref>{{IMDb title|2214629|Whitney: Season 1, Episode 16 - 48 Hours (15 Feb. 2012)}} Retrieved March 28, 2012.</ref> Kasher played the role of Ruben — a gay, deaf man confined to a wheelchair — in an episode of the U.S. television series ''[[Shameless (U.S. TV series)|Shameless]]'' which aired March 18, 2012.<ref>{{IMDb title|2093744|"Shameless" A Great Cause (2012)}} Retrieved March 28, 2012.</ref><ref>{{cite podcast |url=http://thechamps.libsyn.com/webpage/key-from-key-peele- |title=The Champs podcast with guest Keegan-Michael Key |website= |publisher= |host=Neal Brennan, Moshe Kasher and DJ Douggpound |date=March 22, 2012 |time=4:06 |accessdate=March 28, 2012}}</ref>
===Podcasts=== In 2011, Kasher, along with [[Neal Brennan]] (co-writer of ''[[Chappelle's Show]]'') and DJ Douggpound ([[Doug Lussenhop]] of ''[[Tim and Eric Nite Live!]]''), started a [[podcast]] called [[The Champs (podcast)|''The Champs'']].<ref name=SANDIEGO/> Kasher said the following of the podcast in a 2011 interview with SanDiego.com: "It’s Doug dropping sound effects and beats over me and Neal kind of hosting an hour of ridiculous chat. We have a rotating [[Black people|black]] guy guest, there’s a different black guest every week."<ref name=SANDIEGO/> Guests of the show have included actor/comedians [[Wayne Brady]] and [[David Alan Grier]], as well as musician [[Questlove]], [[Pornographic film|adult film]] star [[Lexington Steele]] and professional basketball player [[Blake Griffin]]. The show has strayed from its guest format on occasion with guests such as comedian and actor [[Bobby Lee]], former pornographic actress [[Sasha Grey]], former Major League Baseball player [[Jose Canseco]] and actor [[Aziz Ansari]]. In 2014 ''The Champs'' was named "Best Podcast" as part of ''[[LA Weekly]]''{{'s}} "Best of L.A." issue.<ref>{{cite journal |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->|title=Best Podcast Los Angeles 2014 — The Champs |url=http://www.laweekly.com/los-angeles/best-podcast/BestOf?oid=5108130 |journal=LA Weekly|date=October 2–8, 2014 |volume=36 |issue=46 |accessdate=September 29, 2014}}</ref>
In October 2014, Kasher premiered a new podcast on the [[Nerdist Industries|Nerdist Podcast Network]]. ''Hound Tall Discussion Series'' is a live monthly podcast that covers a single topic. It's "an hour long chat with an expert and a panel of comedians, they learn all there is to know about things".<ref>{{cite web|title=Hound Tall Discussion Series with Moshe Kasher |url=http://www.nerdist.com/podcast_channel/hound-tall-discussion-series-with-moshe-kasher/ |website=nerdist.com |publisher=Nerdist Industries |accessdate=14 October 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141017132047/http://www.nerdist.com/podcast_channel/hound-tall-discussion-series-with-moshe-kasher/ |archivedate=17 October 2014 |df= }}</ref> The first episode was about [[harem]]s and the expert was [[Jillian Lauren]], author of [[Some Girls: My Life in a Harem|Some Girls]], while [[Pete Holmes]] and Beth Stelling made up the comedic panel.<ref>http://www.avclub.com/article/hound-tall-moshe-kasher-brings-new-podcast-airwave-210017</ref>
==Personal life== Kasher married comedian [[Natasha Leggero]] in October 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thecomicscomic.com/2015/10/12/mazel-tov-natasha-leggero-and-moshe-kasher-get-married/ |title=Mazel Tov! Natasha Leggero and Moshe Kasher get married |last=McCarthy |first=Sean L. |date=October 12, 2015 |work=thecomicscomic.com |accessdate=October 13, 2015}}</ref> On February 24, 2018, his wife Natasha announced the birth of their child via Instagram.
==Filmography== * ''[[Sorry, Thanks]]'' (2009) (Andrew) * ''Wish Makers of West Hollywood'' (2010) (waiter) * ''Zoolander 2'' (2016) (Chimney Sweep)
==Television== * ''[[Live at Gotham]]'' (2009), (himself - stand up) * ''[[Chelsea Lately]]'' (2010–present), (himself - panelist) * ''[[Late Night with Jimmy Fallon]]'' (2010, 2012), (himself - stand up) * ''[[John Oliver's New York Stand Up Show]]'' (2011), (himself - stand up) * ''[[The Daily Habit]]'' (2011), (himself - panelist) * ''[[Traffic Light (TV series)|Traffic Light]]'' (2011), (Spike) * ''[[Whitney (TV series)|Whitney]]'' (2012), (waiter) * ''[[Conan (talk show)|Conan]]'' (2012), (himself - stand up) * ''[[Shameless (U.S. TV series)|Shameless]]'' (2012), (Ruben) * ''Moshe Kasher: Live in Oakland'' (2012), (himself - stand up)<ref>http://www.moshekasher.com/</ref> * ''[[Drunk History]]'' (2013), ([[Albert Parsons]]) * ''[[@midnight]]'' (2013–present), (himself) * ''[[The Pete Holmes Show]]'' (2013), (himself - interview) * ''[[Garfunkel and Oates (TV series)]]'' (2014), (Receptionist)<ref>https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3626384/?ref_=nm_flmg_act_6</ref> * ''[[Brooklyn Nine-Nine]]'' (2014), (Chocolate Milk Barista) * ''[[The League]]'' (2014), (November) * ''[[Another Period]]'' (2015), Dr. Goldberg * ''Problematic With Moshe Kasher'' (2017), (himself) * ''The Honeymoon Stand Up Special' (2018), (himself)
== Bibliography == * "Look Before You Leap", a monologue included in the literary collection ''Monologues For Men By Men: Volume Two'' (2003) * ''Kasher in the Rye: The True Tale of a White Boy from Oakland Who Became a Drug Addict, Criminal, Mental Patient, and Then Turned 16'' (2012)
== Discography == * "Moshe Kasher: Live In Oakland" (2013) * ''Everyone You Know Is Going to Die, and Then You Are!'' (2009)
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
== External links == {{Commons category}} * {{Official website|http://moshekasher.com/}} * {{IMDb name|2902915|Moshe Kasher}} * [http://www.thechampsyo.com The Champs Podcast] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20141017132047/http://www.nerdist.com/podcast_channel/hound-tall-discussion-series-with-moshe-kasher/ Hound Tall Discussion Series Podcast]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Kasher, Moshe}} [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1979 births]] [[Category:American memoirists]] [[Category:American podcasters]] [[Category:American stand-up comedians]] [[Category:Jewish American comedians]] [[Category:Jewish male comedians]] [[Category:People from Queens, New York]] [[Category:University of California, Santa Barbara alumni]] [[Category:American television writers]] [[Category:Male television writers]] [[Category:Male actors from Oakland, California]] [[Category:Male actors from New York City]] [[Category:Writers from New York City]] [[Category:Writers from Oakland, California]] [[Category:21st-century American male actors]] [[Category:21st-century American comedians]] [[Category:American male television actors]] [[Category:Comedians from New York City]] [[Category:Upright Citizens Brigade Theater performers]]
